pkgmetadata.longdescription:
ot-sources is a kernel experimental patchset containing performance patches and encryption.
Power users can choose either the BMQ, PDS, MuQSS CPU schedulers.
The TRESOR patch provides increased mitigation from cold boot resistant attacks (only in the 4.14.x series).
Compiler based optimizations are provided by GraySky2's GCC patch and the O3 patch.
The amd-staging-drm-next patches provide increase compatibility and better support for new hardware and features like FreeSync, PowerPlay updates. This USE flag is unstable.
The ROCk kernel driver will install the driver needed for the ROCm platform and better support for AMD GPU enthusiast level hardware. This package pick mostly enhancement commits and drop the compatibility layer provided by KCL. This USE flag is most of the time is broken.
ROCm requires PCIe 3.0 for some older cards except current newer generation cards like VEGA 10 and Vega 7nm. See https://rocm-documentation.readthedocs.io/en/latest/Installation_Guide/Installation-Guide.html#supported-gpus for a full list. This integrated patch will try to remove the compatibility layer and merge features of the ROCk driver / ROCm API.
Older point releases are removed to eliminate some of the previously announced 0-day exploits.

use.flag: Patches the amdgpu DRM kernel driver with latest AMD GPU hardware, PowerPlay updates. You need to define a AMD_STAGING_DRM_NEXT_BUMP_REQUEST version subscription environmental variable with either head, snapshot, dc_ver, amdgpu_version, amdgpu_19_30. head uses the latest commit updated a couple times a week. snapshot is tested instance of head. dc_ver is updated weekly or monthly. amdgpu_version is updated several times a year. amdgpu_19_30 is a snapshot of the tag, and corresponds to 19.30 amdgpu-pro dkms driver but without ROCk enhancements.
Patches the kernel with BFQ fixes and updates from the Liquorix kernel project.
Patches the kernel to use BMQ CPU scheduler, a more simple scheduler.
Patches the kernel with fixes to BMQ.
Builds the kernel.
Applies patches to resolve CVEs (Common Vulnerabilities and Exposures).
Assumes the IO scheduler will be the stock CFS CPU scheduler.
Installs scripts to disable debugging, tracing, verbose output or related code paths.
Patches the kernel for more CPU microarchitecutures

Toggles the merging or removal of commits related to FirePro DirectGMA support. Disabling it may reduces the code size a bit; make it less problematic to update the amdgpu-driver / amd-staging-drm-next part of ROCk. For enhanced SSG (Solid State Graphics) support, you will need to enable this USE flag.
Patches ther kernel with FUTEX_WAIT_MULTIPLE futex syscall option which may be used in the wine-proton package and in Steam Play (based on Proton). It may reduce CPU usage by less than 5%.
Patches the kernel with Con Kolivas patchset and includes his skiplist based MuQSS CPU scheduler.
Patches the kernel to allow for more aggressive O3 compiler optimizations.
Patches the kernel with an alternative skiplist based scheduler.

Patches the kernel with additional Multi GPU enhancements and enthusiast grade AMD GPU hardware support with the latest version of ROCk to unlock the fullest potential of the ROCm API and the hardware. You need to define a ROCK_BUMP_REQUEST version subscription environmental variable with either: latest, head, snapshot, 2_9_0. head is latest commit and updated a couple times a week. snapshot is a tested instance of head. 2_9_0 is a tag release of ROCk. latest is the newest tag release updated a couple times a month to months.
Updates the the /usr/src/linux symlink for every newer release.
Controls application of TRESOR. AES keys are stored in registers instead of RAM.
Patches the kernel with cold boot resistant AES hardware accelerated AES-NI support.
Patches the kernel with cold boot resistant AES using SSE for 32 bit systems.
Builds the external key setting program.
Patches the kernel with cold boot resistant AES using SSE for 64 bit systems.
Patches the kernel with the Ultra Kernel Samepage Merging, a type of page deduper algorithm. Using it may be insecure.
Patches the kernel with Zen Interactive Tuning.

Patches the kernel with selected Zen kernel commits. You will need to define a ZENMISC_WHITELIST_5_3 env variable containing a string of space separated commit IDs. Commits must be oldest-left to newest-right and in topological order with the first commit first and the final commit last if using the same timestamp or split commit. For a full list of commits
The zenmisc set contains patches that add drivers or functionality related to gaming, laptops, optimizations, etc.
for 5.3 see: https://github.com/torvalds/linux/compare/v5.3...zen-kernel:5.3/misc
for 5.4 (possibly provisional) see: https://github.com/torvalds/linux/compare/v5.4...zen-kernel:5.4/zen-sauce
Use the o3, zenmisc, graysky2 USE flags instead of passing their commit IDs.
